Abstract: The role of water depth, and bottom boundary layer turbulence upon lee wave generation in 
sill regions is examined.  Their effect upon vertical mixing is also considered.  Calculations are 
performed using a non-hydrostatic model in cross-section form with a specified tidal forcing.  Initial 
calculations in deeper water, and a sill height such that the sill top is well removed from the 
surrounding bed region, showed that downstream lee wave generation, and associated mixing 
increased as bottom friction coefficient k increased.  This was associated with an increase in current 
shear across the sill.  However, for a given k, increasing vertical eddy viscosity Av reduced vertical 
shear in the across sill velocity, leading to a reduction in lee wave amplitude and associated mixing.  
Subsequent calculations using shallower water, showed that for a given k and Av lee wave generation 
was reduced due to the shallower water depth and changes in the bottom boundary layer.  However in 
this case (unlike in the deep water case) there is an appreciable bottom current.  This gives rise to 
bottom mixing which in shallow water extends to mid-depth and enhances the mid-water mixing that 
is found on the lee side of the sill.  Final calculations with deeper water, but small sill height showed 
that lee waves could propagate over the sill, thereby reducing their contribution to mixing.  In this case 
bottom mixing was the major source of mixing which was mainly confined to the near bed region, with 
little mid-water mixing.

1. INTRODUCTION 33 
 One of the major problems in physical oceanography is how energy of meteorological 34 
and tidal origin is transformed through the internal wave field (Van Haren, 2004) into small 35 
scale mixing processes and how this mixing influences the large scale circulation (e.g. 36 
Samelson 1998, Spall 2001, Saenko and Merrifield 2005, Saenko 2006).  In terms of wind 37 
forcing, recent calculations have shown that vorticity associated with small scale eddies in the 38 
ocean can significantly influence the downward diffusion of the wind’s momentum and hence 39 
mixing at depth (Zhai et al 2005).  In shallow seas, wind forcing in the regions of surface and 40 
bottom fronts gives rise to internal waves which can be trapped in the frontal region, or 41 
propagate away (Davies and Xing 2004, Xing and Davies 2005).  In the case of internal 42 
waves propagating along the thermocline there can be appreciable mixing at the level of the 43 
thermocline, namely “internal mixing” (Van Haren and Howarth 2004), that can lead to 44 
enhanced across thermocline exchange (Rippeth et al 2005) and breakdown.  In shallow sea 45 
areas the existence of cold water bottom domes provides a mechanism for internal wave 46 
trapping and associated mixing with changes in circulation (Davies and Xing 2005, Xing and 47 
Davies 2006a). 48 
 In shelf edge regions where the thermocline intersects the shelf slope, the on-off-shelf 49 
motion of the tide gives rise to an internal tide which propagates into the ocean (see Baines 50 
1995, Vlasenko and Stashchuk, 2006, Vlasenko et al 2005, for a comprehensive review).  51 
However the energy dissipation and mixing due to wave-wave interaction associated with this 52 
radiating tide is thought to be small.  However, recently it has been suggested that internal 53 
mixing of tidal origin occurs in regions of rough topography (e.g. Xing and Davies 2006b,c) 54 
due to its interaction with small scale topography.  Consequently in the last few years 55 
significant modelling and measurements have been made at oceanic features e.g. rides, 56 
seamounts and shelf slopes (Legg and Adcroft 2003, Legg 2004a,b, Hosegood and Van 57 
 4 
Haren (2004), New and Pingree (1990), Van Haren (2004), Legg (2004a,b), Dewey et al 58 
(2005), Gerkema and Zimmerman (1995), Gerkema (2001, 2002), Gillibrand and Amundrud 59 
(2007), Jeans and Sherwin (2001a,b) where there is appreciable small scale topography.  60 
However using models to examine the energy cascade in such areas is particularly difficult 61 
due to the lack of detailed measurements of far field effects along the extensive open 62 
boundaries surrounding these features.  This suggests that detailed measurements and 63 
associated modelling in semi-enclosed regions with abrupt topography and strong tidal 64 
currents e.g. sills in fjords and lochs (e.g. Inall et al., 2004, 2005) could yield insight into the 65 
role of small scale topography upon internal tidal mixing. 66 
 In terms of tidal mixing and dissipation this is particularly large on continental 67 
shelves.  In these regions, strong tidal currents flowing over a rough sea bed produce a thick 68 
(of order 50 m) turbulent bottom boundary layer.  In many regions e.g. shallow (water depth 69 
below 50 m) areas of the European Continental Shelf, the bottom boundary layer thickness 70 
exceeds the water depth and the water column remains well mixed.  In this case the mixing is 71 
termed “external mixing” in that it is produced at the bottom of the water column and diffuses 72 
away from the bottom boundary layer into the water column.  The intensity and vertical 73 
extent of this turbulent boundary layer depends on tidal current strength and bottom 74 
roughness. 75 
 In deeper water or regions of weak tidal currents, the bottom turbulent boundary layer 76 
only occupies a small fraction of the water column (e.g. Davies and Jones 1990) and in 77 
summer time a thermocline forms at depth below a well mixed surface layer.  The position of 78 
the thermocline and the associated circulation field are determined by the balance between 79 
turbulence generation and buoyancy suppression (e.g. Xing and Davies 2001). 80 
 In regions such as banks or sills at the entrance to lochs or fjords where the 81 
topography is rough and changes rapidly on space scales comparable to the tidal excursion 82 
 5 
recent measurements (Inall et al 2004, 2005) suggest that there is appreciable mixing of tidal 83 
origin within the thermocline, namely “internal mixing”.  The small geographical extent of 84 
these regions, and particularly in the case of lochs and fjords the fact that tidal forcing is 85 
through one small open boundary, makes them ideal for modelling studies.  In addition 86 
detailed measurements of tidal forcing and mixing can be performed.  However, as we will 87 
show here, besides detailed measurements of tidal forcing and resulting mixing, significant 88 
additional measurements are required, particularly bed roughness and turbulence over the sill 89 
and in the bottom boundary layer downstream of the sill, in order to close the problem to such 90 
an extent that rigorous model validation is possible. 91 
 Recent measurements in Loch Etive (Inall et al 2004, 2005) and associated modelling 92 
studies showed that a non-hydrostatic model in cross sectional form, with idealized 93 
topography, could reproduce the major features of the hydraulic transition, lee wave 94 
production, and mixing found in the observations (Xing and Davies 2006a, hereafter XD06).  95 
In addition the model demonstrated the importance of small scale topography on the leeside 96 
of the sill, upon “internal mixing” of tidal origin (XD06).  In subsequent calculations Davies 97 
and Xing 2007, hereafter DX07 the importance of stratification and its vertical variation upon 98 
lee wave generation and mixing was examined.  These calculations showed that the value of 99 
the buoyancy frequency in the region of the top of the sill was critical in determining the 100 
extent of lee wave generation (DX07).  In this paper that work is extended to examine the 101 
role of bottom friction effects and the thickness of the turbulent bottom boundary layer of 102 
tidal origin upon lee wave formation and associated mixing in the region of sills. 103 
 The model is identical to that used previously (XD06) and is briefly described in the 104 
next section.  Subsequently (Section 3) results are presented to show the influence of bottom 105 
friction and vertical eddy viscosity, which control turbulence in the bottom boundary layer, 106 
upon lee wave generation and mixing in the region of abrupt topography.  These calculations 107 
 6 
are extended in Section 4, to examine the effect upon lee waves and mixing of water depth 108 
change.  In particular for the case of a shallow region where the bottom boundary layer 109 
thickness is comparable to the height of the sill or bank.  A final section summarized the 110 
major findings of the study, and the extent and comprehensive nature of data sets required for 111 
model validation purposes. 112 
2. NUMERICAL MODEL 113 
As this paper is mainly concerned with how sill depth, aspect ratio and the tidally 114 
generated  bottom turbulent boundary layer influence mixing in sill regions, idealized sill 115 
topography was used in all calculations.  In addition a two dimensional (x, z) cross sectional 116 
form of the model was applied, although this means that along sill and across channel 117 
changes in topography were excluded.  Consequently horizontal gyres that can be produced 118 
by along sill topography or in the region of a bank cannot occur. However, such effects are 119 
outside the scope of this paper where the emphasis is the role played by the bottom turbulent 120 
boundary layer.  Here a simple symmetric form of sill topography and water depths 121 
approximating those of Loch Etive where recent measurements were made (Inall et al 2004, 122 
2005) is used (Fig. 1a,b).  Initially calculations were performed with a sill in a water depth h 123 
= 100 m (Fig. 1a) although subsequently water was shallowed to h = 50 m.  By varying the 124 
sill half width (as), the vertical eddy viscosity (AV) due to tidal mixing, together with water 125 
depth and sill height (Table 1), the influence of these parameters that control the bottom 126 
boundary layer, upon flow field, internal wave spectra and mixing could be determined. 127 
As shown by XD07 the vertical velocity and the presence of a hydraulic transition in 128 
the sill region means that the hydrostatic approximation is not valid and non-hydrostatic 129 
effects must be taken into account.  Following previous modelling in sill regions (XD06) the 130 
MIT model (Adcroft et al., 1997 Marshall et al 1997a,b) which is based on a z coordinate in 131 
the vertical and a finite volume discretization was used.  However other non-hydrostatic 132

 Earlier work (XD06, DX07) that was concerned with the role of small scale 480 
topography, such as localized ripples that are found on sills, or changes in vertical 481 
stratification in sill regions, is extended here to examine the role of bottom turbulent mixing 482 
of tidal origin, and water depth in the region of sills.  In particular the influence of enhanced 483 
bed friction and associated turbulence due to changes in bed roughness reflecting differences 484 
in bed types (e.g. sand or gravel) often found in sill regions is considered.  As bed roughness 485 
increases going from a sand to gravel regime so does bed turbulence, parameterized here in 486 
terms of vertical eddy viscosity.  The effects of both changes in bed friction and vertical eddy 487 
viscosity together with water depth upon mixing and internal wave generation were examined 488 
in shallow sill regions.  Transfer of energy from the barotropic M2 tide into a spectrum of 489 
internal waves was quantified in terms of energy power spectra, with spatial distributions of 490 
Ri number and isotherms quantifying the degree of mixing. 491
